newsitem.title: UK: Morocco tranche A loans a buy-West Merchant Bank.
newsitem.headline: Morocco tranche A loans a buy-West Merchant Bank.

text.p: Morocco is likely to get a credit rating only just below investment grade which should mean the price of its traded foreign debt -- the so-called tranche A loan -- will be at a premium, West Merchant Bank strategist Ousmene Mandeng said on Wednesday.
"Morocco's credit rating could be BB+, a notch below investment grade, putting it in line with Panama and two notches above Argentina," he said in a strategy report.
Morocco's tranche A loan has a historical link to the price of Argentine FRB Brady bonds.

"Substantial structural differences...should not warrant such a close relationship. The combination of relatively low debt to exports and debt to GDP ratios could put it close to Panama and Egypt," Mandeng said.
The tranche A loan is the only liquid Moroccan asset available with $2.8 billion outstanding, out of a total of $4.0 in foreign commercial debt, and an average life of 6.7 years.
A high credit rating for Morocco will mean a tighter spread for the loan.
"Scarcity and the opportunity of geographical diversification should allow tranche A to trade at a premium to comparable credits," Mandeng said.
